item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
In the figure: the next #ComplexityThoughts drawn by an AI.In the issue #16 amazing new papers, from #ComplexSystems foundations to #ClimateChange #Ecosystems and #BioInspiredComputingUnraveling complexity: building knowledge, one paper at a time! Curious and want to know more
Not yet subscribed?
It's never too late, and it's 100% free.https://manlius.substack.com/p/complexity-thoughts-issue-16

item.title: Giorgio Gilestro
item.description: The most common feedback we give to our mentees' presentations is: ‚Äùyour slides are too busy. Remove some data and show only stuff you are actively explaining‚Äù.Yet this is the most common mistake PIs end up making at meetings. My brain now switches off if there is too much irrelevant information on your slides. It's like watching a movie with out of sync audio.Please follow your own brilliant advice to students and cut down to the relevant message!

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: Hey @elduvelle, not joining that other blue place?? üôÇ‚Äã

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
@PessoaBrain @tdverstynen @WiringtheBrain @NicoleCRust @DrYohanJohn @skarthik @yoginho that's a fascinating problem.At the most fundamental level, a system consists of interdependent components/units (not meaning here, specifically, "fundamental units" such as atoms in the Greek sense of the word) identified by causal boundaries that can be specified in some functional/operational/structural sort.Mathematically, i would see it as a generalized network (structure) of causally-related (dynamics and function) units, whose behavior is subject to laws that are allowed to change and evolve (co-evolve with the environment).
A system stores, processes and produces information to keep functioning.
This opens a door to a taxonomy, based on if the system is an observer of itself (and act accordingly) or not. This, in turns, allows one to differentiate between complicate (although linear) systems characterized by some level of predictability (even in presence of noise) and complex (nonlinear) systems with emergent features, thus unpredictable above a given temporal scale.

item.title: Marcus Hutchins :verified:
item.description: The case for leaving Twitter"You‚Äôre not fighting a war, you‚Äôre not stopping Twitter from falling into the hands of the far-right, you‚Äôre selling burgers in a Nazi bar, paying more than you profit in rent. Every dollar Twitter makes in ad revenue is a dollar against everything you stand for."https://throwawayopinions.io/the-paradox-of-intolerance.html?1

item.title: Carl T. Bergstrom
item.description: Meanwhile the cost of creating content with the superficial appearance of well-considered text has fallen off a cliff, thanks to ChatGPT. So filling the web with quality material is less rewarding than ever, and filling it with shit is orders of magnitude cheaper than ever.Maybe someone unseats google before the web becomes a wasteland of ChatGPT-authored, search engine-optimized babble.

item.title: DurstewitzLab
item.description:
Our Perspective on reconstructing computational system dynamics from neural data finally out in Nature Rev Neurosci!
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41583-023-00740-7We survey generative models that can be trained on time series data to mimic the behavior of the underlying neural substrate.

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
More evidence that working memory involves ON/OFF Activity-Silent neural dynamics and patterns of functional connectivity.Cue-specific neuronal ensembles span intermittent rate coding of working memory
https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.10.06.561121

item.title: Dan Goodman
item.description: Idea for a new type of online "conference". Instead of focussing on talks, the idea would be to collectively come up with an annual, short, readable review of new work and trends in the field over the last year. Could that work? Would you be interested in taking part if it could?

item.title: Dr. Katharine Hayhoe
item.description: Climate records are falling like dominoes these days and while, as scientists, we're not surprised (because this is exactly what we've been predicting for decades) it is still shocking to see it real life in front of your own eyes, happening in places you know, to people who you know, as opposed to on your screen and in your data.As I share in this interview with meteorologist and expert communicator Sean Sublette, "it is important to realize that work is being done to slow the rate of warming, although there is far more work that needs to be done. Highlighting the work underway also helps avoid the paralysis of doomism, which can be a natural response to bad news.For those wondering what they can do, she emphasizes that simply talking about it is an important first step. ‚ÄúWhen we look at surveys, we‚Äôre not! We‚Äôre not talking about it,‚Äù she said.Meeting people with common interests and values is a way to begin the conversation. ‚ÄúIf we begin our conversation with something that unites us ‚Äî or that we agree on ‚Äî rather than something that divides us ‚Äî what we disagree on ‚Äî those conversations can be much more positive,‚Äù Hayhoe said.Read more: https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/weather/climate-warming-solutions-science-september-record/article_93efa237-fb4f-5d80-b54d-cc2555f37965.html

item.title: Dr. Katharine Hayhoe
item.description: This week, Pope Francis released Laudato Deum, an update on the 2015 encyclical. It's not so much a breath of fresh air as it is a bucket of ice water, straight to the face of those who are standing in the way of and delaying climate progress. Here are a few highlights:On the science: "Despite all attempts to deny, conceal, gloss over or relativize the issue, the signs of climate change are here + increasingly evident. No one can ignore the fact that in recent years we've witnessed extreme weather phenomena."On inequity: "There are those who would place responsibility on the poor, since they have many children. As usual, it would seem that everything is the fault of the poor. Yet the reality is that a low, richer percentage of the planet contaminates more than the poorest 50%."On denial within the church: "I feel obliged to make these clarifications, which may appear obvious, because of certain dismissive and scarcely reasonable opinions that I encounter, even within the Catholic Church."On the root issue: "The greater problem is...the obsession to increase human power beyond anything imaginable, before which nonhuman reality is a mere resource at its disposal. Everything that exists ceases to be a gift for which we should be thankful and instead becomes a slave."On the merchants of doubt, delay, and denial: "The ethical decadence of real power is disguised thanks to marketing and false information, useful tools in the hands of those with greater resources to employ them to shape public opinion."On the delusion or excuse that it's a niche issue: "Once & for all, let us put an end to the irresponsible derision that would present this issue as something purely ecological, romantic, frequently subject to ridicule by economic interests. Let us admit that it is a human + social problem."On leadership at the upcoming COP: "We must move beyond the mentality of appearing to be concerned but not having the courage needed to produce substantial changes. May those taking part in the Conference ... demonstrate the nobility of politics and not its shame."And finally, "To the powerful, I can only repeat this question: ‚ÄúWhat would induce anyone, at this stage, to hold on to power, only to be remembered for their inability to take action when it was urgent and necessary to do so?"Read it here. It's not too long and these are just the highlights! https://www.vatican.va/content/francesco/en/apost_exhortations/documents/20231004-laudate-deum.html

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Leaving aside the specific data issues (improbable duplications) in this S√ªdhof paper, the data have been shared and commenters are beginning to reanalyse them. It may be an eye-opener for some people to see how the sausage is made in an electrophysiology paper. Yet another reason to require data sharing as standard policy.https://pubpeer.com/publications/DAF32F6DB6C166337E5381F769AE52

item.title: Alex McLean
item.description:
I'm looking forward to 1993
Edit: some context:
- This wasn't a proposal for a european rail network, it's a rough transfer of the London Underground map to Europe
- It does show that the eurostar would go from a lot of UK stations, a plan that was sadly cancelled
